title: Partnership Dynamics
description: Explore how your two attachment styles interact and dance together.

questions.text: What dynamic do we tend to fall into during stress?
choices: One pursues while one withdraws
We both seek reassurance from each other
We both pull back and give space
We stay steady and work through it together

therapeutic.rationale: Stress dynamics reveal combined attachment patterns. Pursue-withdraw is the anxious-avoidant pairing; mutual-reassurance is double-anxious; mutual-withdrawal is double-avoidant; steady-together is secure functioning. Most couples have a predictable stress dance.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: This question helps you see your joint pattern. Pursue-withdraw is the most common painful cycle. Name it to change it.
therapeutic.whenSame: If you both selected the same answer, you agree on your dynamic. This awareness is the foundation for change.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's your stress dynamic as a couple? How does it affect you? What would a healthier dynamic look like?

questions.text: How do our attachment styles complement each other?
choices: Your groundedness calms my anxiety
Your warmth helps me open up more
Your independence respects my space needs
Your expressiveness draws me out

therapeutic.rationale: Complementary attachment creates growth potential. Groundedness-calming helps anxious types settle; warmth-opening helps avoidant types connect; independence-respect honors space needs; expressiveness-drawing helps reserved types share. Different attachment styles can heal each other.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different answers show what each values in the other. Your partner sees a different gift in your attachment style than you might realize.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared answers suggest alignment in how you see your complementarity. You both appreciate how you balance each other.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner's attachment style help you? Have you told them? What do you give them in return?

questions.text: Where do our attachment styles create friction?
choices: I want more closeness than you're comfortable with
I need more space than you're comfortable with
We have different communication needs
We recover from conflict differently

therapeutic.rationale: Style friction reveals attachment mismatch points. Closeness-mismatch is anxious-avoidant tension; space-mismatch is avoidant-anxious tension; communication-mismatch affects understanding; recovery-mismatch extends conflict. Identifying friction points allows targeted work.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different friction answers show each sees different tension. Explore both perspectivesâ€”both are valid friction points.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared friction awareness means you're aligned on where work is needed. Address your shared friction point together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Where do your attachment styles create friction? How do you handle it currently? What would reduce the friction?

questions.text: What have we learned to do when our styles clash?
choices: Take breaks to self-regulate, then reconnect
Name the pattern we're in
Ask for what we need directly
Give each other grace and patience

therapeutic.rationale: Clash skills show adaptive coping development. Break-taking prevents escalation; pattern-naming creates awareness; direct-asking prevents guessing; grace-giving prevents shame. These skills transform attachment clashes from relationship-threatening to growth opportunities.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different clash skills show different learned strategies. You may need to combine multiple approaches for effective navigation.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared clash skills mean aligned strategy. You've developed a shared approach to navigating attachment differences.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you do when attachment styles clash? What works best? What skill would you like to develop?

questions.text: How can we better support each other's attachment needs?
choices: More proactive reassurance before anxiety builds
More respect for space without taking it personally
More checking in about what each needs
More patience when one is triggered

therapeutic.rationale: Mutual support improvements guide relationship growth. Proactive-reassurance prevents anxiety escalation; space-respect honors autonomy; checking-in improves attunement; triggered-patience enables recovery. Your partner is telling you how to better support them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different support improvements show different needs. Each of you needs different things for better support. Provide what your partner asked for.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared support needs suggest aligned priorities. Focus your shared effort on this improvement.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How could your partner better support your attachment needs? Have you asked directly? What would make the biggest difference?
